importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article is published on this date, marking the release of Sir Philip Pullman's latest book, The Rose Field, and highlighting ongoing debates about AI and copyright in the UK.
A government consultation on AI and copyright was launched in December 2024, attracting 11,500 responses, setting the stage for potential legal reforms to address AI scraping of creative works.

keyTakeAways: Sir Philip Pullman is urging the UK government to revise copyright laws to prevent unauthorized scraping of writers' works by AI systems.
Writers such as Kate Mosse and Richard Osman have criticized AI scraping, arguing it undermines creative industries and constitutes a form of theft.
Sir Philip claims that all authors' work has been scraped without compensation, comparing the practice to 'stealing' and calling it 'wicked' and immoral.
He emphasizes that creators should be paid for their work being used to train AI, stating: 'They can do what they like with my work if they pay me for it.'
The UK government launched a consultation on AI and copyright in December 2024, with 11,500 responses, and has formed expert working groups on AI and copyright.
Sir Philip’s novel The Rose Field (Book of Dust Volume Three) is set to release on 23 October 2025, completing the second trilogy about Lyra Silvertongue.
The books explore themes of imagination, freedom, and resistance to authoritarian control, with the Magisterium in the series depicting real-world parallels to education and religious power.
Sir Philip rejects labeling his work as fantasy, distinguishing himself from JRR Tolkien, and instead frames his writing as a reflection of real-world human experience through imaginative perception.
He criticizes current education policies for suppressing creativity and imagination, advocating for a more open and inquisitive approach to learning.
He believes in the reality of imagination—such as ghosts, hopes, and love—as tangible but non-measurable experiences, which are central to Lyra’s journey.

Sir Philip is writing a memoir about his childhood and upbringing, and speculates that his daemon would be a corvid (raven), inspired by the bird’s intelligence and mythological role as a storyteller.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Sir Philip Pullman, renowned author of the His Dark Materials and Book of Dust series, has urged the UK government to reform copyright laws to prevent the unauthorized scraping of writers' books by AI systems. He argues that such scraping—where literary works are used to train AI without compensation—is immoral, exploitative, and akin to theft, asserting that creators should be paid. Writers including Kate Mosse and Richard Osman have echoed these concerns, warning that AI scraping could undermine the future of creative industries. The UK government has responded by launching a consultation on AI and copyright in December 2024, with over 11,500 responses and the formation of expert working groups. Pullman, who is completing his Book of Dust trilogy with the release of The Rose Field on 23 October 2025, also emphasizes the importance of imagination as a form of perception, using Lyra’s journey to illustrate how imagination can reveal realities beyond physical measurement. He criticizes current education policies and organized religion as suppressors of curiosity, and while he rejects the label of 'fantasy writer,' he believes his stories reflect real human experiences through imaginative lens. He also shares personal reflections, including a memoir on his childhood and a speculative idea that his daemon would be a raven, a symbol of storytelling and intelligence.
title: Author Philip Pullman calls on government to act over 'wicked' AI scraping
